text.p: A host of rumours about Swiss pharmaceutical group Roche triggered a steep rise in its shares, helping the blue-chip Swiss Market Index (SMI) reach new highs above 4,100 points, dealers said.
Roche certificates soared 765 francs, or nearly seven percent, to 11,935 in heavy volume after temporarily rising to an all-time high at 12,500.
Dealers cited rumours Roche might merge with foreign drug companies or dispose of its fragrances business. A Roche spokesman declined to comment on market rumours.
The SMI closed 92.3 points, or 2.29 percent, higher at 4,115.4 and the all-share Swiss Performance Index (SPI) surged 57.14 points, or 2.21 percent, to 2,638.73.
Volumes were relatively high, with a total of more than 3.9 billion francs traded on the exchange. Daily volume usually ranges between 1.5 billion and two billion francs.
Roche was also buoyed by high demand from derivatives- related transactions, one trader noted.
Other pharmaceuticals and chemicals such as Novartis, Clariant and EMS, also posted gains. Novartis registered shares edged up 24 francs at 1,570.
Sulzer, which was a winner on Tuesday after announcing plans to float 25 percent of its Sulzer Medica unit, gave up four francs to close at 978 after profit taking.

One dealer said Sulzer's decision sparked hopes for other spin-offs. This led to rises in potential spin-off candidates such as Oerlikon-Buehrle, Swissair and Alusuisse. Swissair gained 56 francs, or 4.7 percent, to 1,251.
Among the banks, UBS bearer shares fell three francs to 1,152.
